dtliExcerpt: The two exclamation points in the title are a super-spoiler for “Gutenberg! The Musical!,” a ticklishly funny but, well, paper-thin show about two theater-smitten fellows determined to put on a big Broadway show about the inventor of the printing press.
bwwExcerpt: With Mr. Gad and Mr. Rannells pinballing around the stage under the direction of Alex Timbers (“Here Lies Love,” “Moulin Rouge!”), working up visible sweat as they dash between characters, “Gutenberg!” proffers much comic ingenuity. The silly accents are a delight. Cockney in 15th-century Germany? Why not? Still, even at a fairly pacey two hours the fun eventually turns to wheel-spinning, since the central gag—the ludicrous mismatch between content and form—is established from the start and then

https://www.wsj.com/articles/gutenberg-the-musical-review-broadway-andrew-rannells-josh-gad-420d906c

Andrew Rannells and Josh Gad Matthew MurphyNew York

The two exclamation points in the title are a super-spoiler for “Gutenberg! The Musical!,” a ticklishly funny but, well, paper-thin show about two theater-smitten fellows determined to put on a big Broadway show about the inventor of the printing press.
